body: The moon hung full above the Brooklyn waterfront, adding its silvery winter light to the reflected sparkling of the holiday skyline. And here and there, in eddies and backwaters, along the edges of fast-running rips and under the dock lights that ring the harbor, striped bass, the last gift of the angling season, fed on schools of frantic spearing,
title: An East River Expedition Just Before Christmas

body: Seeking to ease a housing shortage that is growing worse by the month, the Giuliani administration is preparing a broad plan to open up manufacturing areas to residential development while eliminating regulations that it thinks are discouraging housing construction in New York City. Officials said the plan would be the city's most direct response
title: Giuliani Offers Plan to Ease Restrictions on New Housing

body: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew will be able to use his new power to hire school superintendents almost immediately in 27 of the city's 32 school districts. The timing of the legislation enacted yesterday coincides with the final months of three-year contracts between all the local school boards and their district superintendents. Five local school
title: Timing Allows Crew To Respond Quickly

body: THERE it is: an old seven- or eight-story brick manufacturing building with big windows across the front, standing vacant or partly vacant and forlorn on a side street in TriBeCa, SoHo, North Gramercy, Flatiron, Chelsea, the Meat Market area, the Financial District, across the river in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn -- anywhere in New York
title: Loft Market Grows, at Lofty Prices

author: Ross Sandler, former New York City Transportation Commissioner, is director of the Center for New York City Law at New York Law School.
body: There is always an excuse to defer caring for New York City's bridges, highways, school buildings and other public structures. The reason this time is a 19th century restriction found in the state Constitution. Under this provision, the city can borrow no more than 10 percent of the market value of its taxable real property, a sensible limit when
title: On the Road To Ruin

body: A Scandinavian Holiday Boutique The annual Scandinavian Christmas boutique of the American-Scandinavian Foundation, an educational group, will be held Friday through Sunday in the Alvar Aalto Penthouse of the Institute for International Education, 809 United Nations Plaza (First Avenue and 46th Street). Food and other items will be sold. A
title: Food Notes

body: Love must be unconditional to be true. For love to be true, it must involve hate. Loving an inanimate object can never be true love -- unless of course you are talking about Brooklyn, a sunset or the New York Yankees. While watching a French news program on cable television, Martine Lindquist saw a story about the esoteric open discussions on
title: New Paris Import: Pondering the Big Questions at Cafes . . .

body: In the best science fiction movies, there are parallel universes, worlds within worlds, secrets locked in forgotten codes. And so it is with the New York subways, which were envisioned to go far more places -- in a skein of routes that might dazzle present-day straphangers -- under bold plans that have faded into distant memory. Some of this
title: Subway Planners' Lofty Ambitions Are Buried as Dead-End Curiosities

body: Hoping to end a four-year battle that has delayed repairs of its deteriorating East River bridges, New York City has reached a settlement with people who consider sandblasting a health risk and has agreed to new environmental safeguards on bridge-repair projects. In settling a lawsuit that arose over the sandblasting of lead-based paint from the
title: Accord Reached in Suit Over East River Bridges

body: NEW YORK Mayor Concedes on Meter Fines After intense criticism from Council members and residents, Mayor Giuliani agreed to roll back the fines for expired meters in Manhattan north of 96th Street and in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island. The fine for an expired meter will be reduced to $20 plus a $5 state surcharge, except in Manhattan
title: METRO DIGEST

body: For half a century, Gizella Weisshaus followed a trail of whispers. She followed it three times to Switzerland, searching for a bank account her father opened there during World War II, hoping his family could escape the Nazis and use the money to rebuild their lives. For Mrs. Weisshaus, who lost everyone and everything in the war, memory was the
title: In Lawsuit Against Swiss Banks, A Hope to Do Justice to a Father's Memory

body: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week: American Medserve Corp., Naperville, Ill., an initial public offering of 5.4 million shares. William Blair & Co. Amresco Inc., Dallas, 7.76 million shares. Robinson-Humphrey Co. Autobond Acceptance Corp., Austin, Tex., an initial public offering of 1 million shares. Boston
title: Offerings of Equities Expected for This Week

body: IT is an imposing building, on Havemeyer Street in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, a former convent made of mellowed brick piled four stories high, complete with turrets and enormous windows. For years, this 100-year-old building was derelict, bought from the Sisters of the Order of St. Dominic in the late 70's by the caretaker of the Church
title: A Former Convent Becomes a Co-op

body: The city's greenmarkets are bountiful sources of fresh produce. A few have closed for the year. Several others will close between now and the end of December, and the remainder stay open year-round on designated days, usually from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. Here is a list of markets and when they are open: MANHATTAN Bowling Green Broadway and Battery Place
title: How Green Is My Market: A Guide to Fresh Produce in the Streets

body: To the Editor: After reading your article, I felt the need to share my own Plan Eat Thailand experience. Having recently moved to Williamsburg, I decided to dine at Plan Eat Thailand. You can imagine my astonishment! I looked in vain for any Republican former box-office heavyweights. Where was Bruce, where was Sylvester, and for heaven's sake,
title: Diners Know the Difference Between the Two Planets

body: Barbara C. Salken, a professor at the Pace University School of Law in White Plains, died on Oct. 17 at Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla. She was 49 and lived in Chappaqua, N.Y. She suffered a long illness, according to the law school, where she had taught criminal law and procedure for 13 years. For three of the last seven years, she was
title: Barbara C. Salken, Law Professor, 49

body: Rebecca Anne Churchill, the daughter of Marcia Knott Churchill of Arlington, Va., and Neil E. Churchill of Doylestown, Pa., was married yesterday to Laurence Michael Gomez, the son of Roberta B. Honig of Brooklyn and the late Ronald H. Gomez. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York. Ms.
title: Ms. Churchill, Mr. Gomez

body: FROM the Navy Yard in Williamsburg to the Army base at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn was a borough at war in late 1943. There seemed to be soldiers everywhere: local boys home on leave, others enjoying themselves before shipping out to Europe and thousands more in training in the New York area. Among them was a wide-eyed 20-year-old from a small town in
title: Dese, Dem and Dole

body: Every Thursday at lunch time, Lieut. Federico Narvaez pulled his sensible Chevrolet Cavalier up to his 9-year-old daughter's parochial school and began his favorite shift of the week, as lunchroom monitor. ''The kids loved him,'' said one colleague. ''They would hang all over him.'' At the 70th Precinct station house in the East Flatbush section of
title: A Friendly, Joking Boss And a 'Nice Family Man'

body: It was a sales pitch aimed at the heart of every New Yorker who ever dashed back to a double-parked car a moment too late, or forgot which day the street sweeper was coming by. ''Tired of parking tickets?'' the business cards asked. ''Call the experts and save.'' Between 1991 and 1996, prosecutors say, more than 200 motorists decided to make that
title: Beating Tickets, but Not the Authorities

body: An article last Sunday about living in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn misstated the area's form of government in 1855, when it became part of Brooklyn. Williamsburgh, as it was then spelled, was a city, not a village.
title: Corrections

body: Benefit Auction Decorators Walk, D & D Building, 979 Third Avenue (58th Street); (212) 319-7100. An auction of six one-of-a-kind chairs and 25 pillows, all in fabrics from Decorators Walk, will take place tonight at 6:30 P.M., to benefit Furnish a Future, the furniture-donation program of the Partnership for the Homeless. Tickets, including a
title: Calendar: Benefits, Exhibitions And Tours

body: Despite escalating efforts by the New York City Police Department to fight drug dealing, Federal and local law enforcement officials say increasing supplies of cheap and potent heroin have entered the city in recent months to be sold in the city and around the metropolitan area. The officials said the surge in Colombian heroin smuggling that began
title: Police Battle Surge in Cheap Heroin

body: AT certain hours, Bedford Avenue seems calm for a thoroughfare. But at other times, as when it is so crowded there are lines for Sunday brunch, you could maybe -- maybe -- mistake it for a Manhattan streetscape. O.K., maybe not. But it is close. There is that lovely Manhattan skyline, stretching across the East River, just a subway stop away. There
title: Trendy Ambiance and Manhattan Views

body: UPPER EAST SIDE The Rescuing of Many Jews By the Righteous in Italy ''The Righteous Enemy'' is a documentary film that tells the story of how members of the Italian Army and diplomatic corps saved the life of a Jew during the Holocaust. The film, released in 1987 but not widely distributed, will be shown on Wednesday in a collaboration between
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: Politics and Shoe Leather: A Party With No Campaign Kenneth Cole, the trendy shoe designer with the political touch, used ''Get Out and Vote'' as the theme for the opening party on Thursday night at his third Manhattan store. The 5,000-square-foot store is at 597 Broadway, off Houston Street in SoHo. Mr. Cole, married to Maria Cuomo, daughter of
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.

body: A state court has blocked sandblasting on all New York City bridges, pending environmental studies and public hearings, in a ruling that deepens a controversy arising from lead-paint removal on the Williamsburg Bridge. The ruling by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court expands an earlier order halting sandblasting only on the Williamsburg
title: Court Halts Sandblasting on Bridges Until Studies Are Completed

body: NEW YORK Javits Center on the Mend The Jacob K. Javits Convention Center is luring back trade shows after overhauling its operations, and is expected to make a profit this year. Show organizers and state officials say that new executives seem to have eliminated much of the corruption and shoddy service that drove away business and caused the
title: Metro Digest

body: There was a time when the air was filled with the whistles and toots of more than a hundred ferries crisscrossing New York Harbor. Men and women still dressed for dinner. People wrote with fountain pens and rode trolleys to work. With the advent of bridges and tunnels, however, the ferries all but disappeared. Now they're coming back. Today there
title: Traveling by Ferry, Once Common in New York Harbor, May Be Again

body: Dorothy Ellen Palmer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Guy Palmer 2d of Savannah, Ga., was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Jordan Straub, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester J. Straub of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. David S. Hoag, the rector of Christ Episcopal Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the church. Msgr. Anthony Dalla Villa, the
title: Robert J. Straub, Dorothy E. Palmer

body: On the edge of Newtown Creek, the city is poised to modernize and expand its largest sewage treatment plant -- a more than $1 billion venture that will bring the 30-year-old facility into compliance with Federal clean water laws. Community leaders, nauseated by the stench from the plant and fed up with having so much of the city's waste dumped in
title: Sewage Plant: No vs. Maybe

body: 'Inside/Out' Momenta Art 72 Berry Street, near North 10th Street Williamsburg, Brooklyn Through Oct. 7 This thought-provoking little show of six artists mulls over various forms of site-specificity while considering some of the artistic possibilities of architecture and design. It includes meticulous models by James Mills, including ''Gas Leak,'' a
title: Art in Review

body: It has been discussed for a decade, undergone several incarnations and been led by three different people. Now, leaders of a committee creating a plan for future development along the waterfront in Williamsburg and Greenpoint say they will release a draft plan later this month. ''It will be a blueprint for redevelopment of the
title: Future Vision: Planners Head in Different Directions

body: It's back. The downtown art scene shifted into gear last week with three frenzied nights of gallery openings in Chelsea and SoHo. Especially SoHo. There, the end of summer was signaled by the uneven cultural melange that is the fourth annual SoHo Arts Festival. Bigger and maybe more organized than ever, the four-day festival enlivened the
title: Culture and Commerce Live Side by Side in SoHo

body: When Chris Doyle wiped his forehead in the noon sunshine yesterday, the flecks of gold leaf on his fingers sparkled like glitter. Beneath his feet, the corroded pedestrian stairway on the Manhattan side of the Williamsburg Bridge gleamed, with the fruit of his labor, like the vault at Fort Knox. A steady stream of pedestrians, many carrying
title: Artist Transforms Bleak Bridge Walk Into Urban Dream

body: NEW YORK Voters Refused at Some Polls Voters who turned up for a bitterly contested primary in Brooklyn were turned away from the polls at scores of polling places because election workers had failed to deliver the voting machines in time. The problem persisted into the afternoon, raising the prospect that the election would have to be held again.
title: Metro Digest

body: This was when Nydia M. Velazquez had expected to hit her stride. After staking out a position as a vocal spokeswoman on issues like immigration and housing, the two-term Congresswoman had hoped to establish herself this year as a major Congressional player. Instead, this has been a year filled with frustration as Ms. Velazquez, the first Puerto
title: With Redistricting in Vogue, Velaquez Takes a Spot in Line

body: NEW YORK Classes Open Amid Confusion With classrooms crammed into supply closets, cordoned-off in auditoriums and plunked into locker rooms, New York City public schools opened to the worst overcrowding in decades. Across the city, there were signs of strain and confusion from the overcrowding, unfinished construction and the forced reorganization
title: Metro Digest

body: Fancy-Food Grocery Novello, a 10,000-square-foot fancy-food store, opens today at 333 East 38th Street. It has arrived in Manhattan by way of Westchester County, a branch of John Chung's year-old Tarrytown Gourmet. Rob Wilson, the manager and a partner, said the store features smoked salmon, olives, cheeses, charcuterie, produce and prepared food.
title: Food Notes

body: Like the star-filled runway show staged by the rap magazine Vibe last Friday, hip-hop fashion has attracted a sparkling sheaf of celebrity entrepreneurs, like Shaquille O'Neal, Spike Lee, the entertainment mogul Russell Simmons, Chuck D. of the rap group Public Enemy and the newest and most unlikely entrant this summer, Mike Tyson. These are just
title: The Hip-Hop Challenge: Longevity

author: Ellen Pall's most recent novel is ''Among the Ginzburgs.'' Her last article for the Magazine was about the children's entertainer Marc Weiner.
body: IT IS RAINING ON THE MORNING OF MAY 3, nasty, chilly showers that add a smell of damp to the scant charms of the shabby-genteel Gramercy Park Hotel. The third annual Gramercy International Contemporary Art Fair will officially open here at 6, and by noon Kenny Schachter is up to his ankles in art. Last night, alarmed by the tininess of his quarters
title: The Do-It-Yourself Dealers

body: Great Moments in 'D.I.Y.' History 1982: Gracie Mansion, a D.I.Y. forerunner, shows artists like David Wojnarowicz in a former East Village beauty shop. 1990-91: The art crash sends the New York gallery world into a slump, providing an opening for the huddled masses of excluded dealers and artists. October 1991: D.I.Y. invades cyberspace with ''The
title: The Do-It-Yourself Art World

body: SAVE for a few white lilies sprouting from gaudy plastic flower arrangements near the stage, there is little evidence that the New York Christian Life Center in East New York, Brooklyn, is a church. There is hardly any Christian iconography. The setting is like a television studio, with a band near the stage playing snappy interludes, contemporary
title: The Rev. Doctor Banker

body: After three years of repair work, the two Brooklyn-bound upper lanes of the Manhattan Bridge are scheduled to reopen to car traffic today, providing some relief to drivers who have put up with seemingly unending repair work there. The anticipated return of cars and trucks to the upper deck of the seven-lane bridge is also expected to lighten
title: After 3 Years Of Repairs, Deck of Bridge Set to Reopen

body: Transit Authority officials call it ''bunching'' -- the urban phenomenon in which would-be passengers wait interminably at a bus stop, then two or three buses show up at the same time. Bus riders just call it annoying. Bunching means long waits and long lines at bus stops, among the top complaints heard by transit officials. It is also considered
title: Field Dispatcher Program Is Tested In an Effort to Lure Bus Riders Back

body: Emmy Delacruz and her best friend, Manuela Guzman, had their routine down even before the first float: gyrate furiously to the deafening bass line for about 30 seconds, then scream: ''Republica Dominicana!'' ''You look around,'' yelled Ms. Delacruz, 18, ''and you can't believe there are this many Dominicans in the whole world!'' To the
title: Dominicans Celebrate Growth in Volume

body: In a major infusion of corporate cash that housing experts say has come at a crucial time, executives of 19 large New York City companies said yesterday that they had invested $147 million in a program to rehabilitate rundown city-owned apartment buildings. The investment, which is to be matched by $147 million in city money, represents the largest
title: $147 Million Is Pledged To Renovate Apartments

body: A police detective deployed as part of a crackdown on drug trafficking in high-crime precincts was shot by a sniper as he stood on a Brooklyn street corner yesterday afternoon. The detective's bulletproof vest deflected the bullets, saving the officer's life, officials said. Detective David Joseph, 34, was shot three times as he used a public
title: Detective Shot 3 Times by Sniper Is Saved by Bulletproof Vest

body: South Brooklyn Legal Services has always had a weighty roster of class-action lawsuits on behalf of the city's poor. Among those it has won are a case for women with AIDS who had been denied disability benefits, and another for special-education students who had not been properly screened. Those days are over. Squeezed by Federal financing cuts and
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE;Legal Aid Agencies Have a New Cause, Their Own Survival

body: South Brooklyn Legal Services has always had a weighty roster of class-action lawsuits on behalf of the city's poor. Among those it has won are a case for women with AIDS who had been denied disability benefits, and another for special-education students who had not been properly screened. Those days are over. Squeezed by Federal financing cuts and
title: Legal Aid Agencies Have a New Cause, Their Own Survival

body: THE Art Moderne industrial building in Long Island City, Queens, that once served as the Knickerbocker Laundry plant is a familiar sight to commuters on the Long Island Rail Road. Katherine Petrin calls it "stunning." Ms. Petrin is a student at the Columbia University Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation who has done a thesis
title: PERSPECTIVES;From a Laundry to a Perfume Factory to a Church

body: A 10-year-old Brooklyn boy arguing with his best friend outside a church in Williamsburg yesterday used a gun he had taken from his grandmother's bedroom to fatally shoot the other boy, also 10, the police said. Relatives said the boy accused in the shooting, whose name was not released because of his age, ran home afterward and hid in his bedroom,
title: Boy, 10, Accused of Shooting Best Friend to Death

body: An investigation into counterfeit designer clothing, sunglasses and watches led to sweltering, hazardous sweatshops where teen-agers worked 70-hour weeks for below-minimum wages, the Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said yesterday in announcing the arrests of six men on charges of violating trademark laws. Saying that two Williamsburg
title: 6 Are Accused of Violating Trademark Laws

body: THE Legislature and Governor relaxed last week after finally reaching agreement on the latest state budget ever. Lawmakers got their pork -- money for pet projects back home. And Gov. George E. Pataki, though an abject failure in meeting his goal of bringing in a conservative budget on time, nonetheless pronounced himself deeply satisfied because,
title: Metro Matters;While Albany Fiddled, Many Got Burned

body: TWO sweets purveyors in homey-looking storefronts -- painted white, pale yellow and lime and decorated with vintage kitchen accessories -- have opened on Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village. Last Thursday, Magnolia Bakery opened at 401 Bleecker Street (West 11th Street). It is a second-career partnership for Alysa Salvatore, a jazz singer turned
title: The Talk and Tastes of Bleecker Street

body: Happy Birthday, Voter Q. I recently received a large postcard on my birthday with the message "A Million Good Wishes for a Happy Birthday and many more from your senator Roy M. Goodman." The postcard states, "Not Printed At Government Expense," but it carries a bulk-rate postage stamp. I'm wondering how Senator Goodman knew my birth date and who
title: F.Y.I.

body: Walk through this city's desolate warehouse district by the Hudson River, and you'll see big graffiti-covered buildings once used to make cigarettes and distribute groceries. Walk through the same area in a year or two, and with any luck you'll see a vibrant neighborhood of art galleries splashed with the work that artists are creating in cavernous
title: CITY LIFE;Among the Loading Docks, Dreams of a Lively Art District

body: A day after a ferryboat collided with several vessels on the East River while the waterway was packed with boats for a Fourth of July fireworks display, the Coast Guard was investigating the cause but said it had no plans to limit the number of boats allowed on the river for such events. Coast Guard officials would not say whether the fact that
title: Coast Guard Won't Limit Boat Crowds

body: When city officials began a $500 million overhaul of the Williamsburg Bridge eight years ago, it created almost constant traffic congestion. Now the situation is about to get even worse, as city officials will close four of the bridge's eight lanes on Monday, for about two years. Workers will tear down concrete and asphalt and build new foundations
title: Bridge Traffic, Already Bad, Will Get Worse

body: Ending a tumultuous courtroom feud between factions of a leading Hasidic sect in Brooklyn, New York State's highest court yesterday upheld the purchase of the former Grand Rabbi's Brooklyn house by a dissident group. Though the case turned on arcane principles of real estate law, it provided an unusual window on the tightknit relationships and the
title: Sale of a Grand Rabbi's Home Is Upheld

body: After two consecutive years of plunging citywide crime rates, fresh New York City police statistics show that murder, burglary, robbery and other serious crimes are dropping sharply again this year across the city and once again at an accelerating pace. Despite several recent high-profile crimes -- notably the beatings of women in Central Park and
title: 1996 Data Show Crime Rates Are Still Falling in New York

body: NEW YORK is the best place in the world for people who like to eat. This city has never needed to apologize for the quality of its food. Reading old restaurant guides makes it clear that a hungry person has been able to find almost anything here for a very long time. The writer Rian James ate his way through the 1920's, sampling an extraordinary
title: Satisfying Appetites As Varied as New York

body: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract. MANHATTAN GREENWICH VILLAGE $360,000 130 Barrow Street 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. duplex, penthouse condo in a former garage building; elevator, 2 fireplaces, terrace,
title: Residential Resales

body: CUCINA** (718) 230-0711; 256 Fifth Avenue, near Garfield Place, Park Slope; (c) American Express, Mastercard, Visa This attractive Italian restaurant, with painted tin ceiling, mural and antique wood serving tables, has a rustic Tuscan feel. For starters consider caramelized onion tart with olives; artichoke with basil dipping sauce, and roasted
title: GOOD EATING;Where Brooklyn Meets to Eat

body: In a resounding victory for residents who live near the Williamsburg Bridge and a setback for the city, a state appellate court has ordered an immediate halt to sandblasting on the bridge. The 5-0 decision handed down on Thursday by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court is the latest chapter, but perhaps not the last, in a long-running
title: Court Halts Williamsburg Bridge Cleaning in Battle Over Showers ofLead Paint

body: As Manhattan customers go, they were prized targets for commercial garbage haulers: the main Federal office building, a Federal jail, the Bank of New York and the Woolworth Building. They were also, prosecutors say, the latest in a long line of victims of a Mafia-controlled cartel, in which private trash-hauling companies inflated fees and rigged
title: Trash Haulers Face New List Of Charges About Fees

body: As fires go, it was minor. Just an empty truck damaged; no one hurt. But the blaze was intended as a menacing message for a Brooklyn company trying to get a foothold in New York City's lucrative garbage-carting business. It backfired. Instead, the company, the Chambers Paper Fibres Corporation, became the conduit through which the Manhattan
title: When the Mafia Got Greedy, a Garbage Hauler Went Undercover

body: It is almost time to put the school year to bed, so let the summer street games begin. In the brick courtyard of Confucius Plaza in Chinatown, a group of teen-agers play handball against a wall obstructed by a light pole and fire plugs. They speak to each other in Chinese, but they put plenty of English on the ball. "It's not a real handball court,
title: Stoopball? Ringalevio? Hey, It's the 90's!;Flash, Speed and Money Replace Old Street Games For Children of the City

body: The Art Exchange 60 Broad Street Financial district Through June 15 This "(alternative) alternative art fair," organized for the Alliance for Downtown New York, unfolds through five desolate floors in a vacant office building near the New York Stock Exchange. It is, literally and figuratively, about as downtown as you can get. Its participants are
title: Art in Review

body: The beer is called Brooklyn Lager. But for the past eight years, it has been made in Utica, N.Y., and shipped by truck to Brooklyn. How come? It took us eight years to get into a position where we felt sure enough about ourselves to invest millions to build a brewery in Brooklyn," said Stephen K. Hindy, who with a fellow Park Slope neighbor, Thomas
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WILLIAMSBURG;Could the Dodgers Follow? Brewing Returns to Brooklyn

body: When Carol Gattuso Hausler was 8 years old, she fearfully boarded a train bound for Port Royal, Pa., leaving her Italian immigrant family and Williamsburg, Brooklyn, behind as she went off to "see America." "I had no idea where they were taking me," Mrs. Hausler said last week. "I thought they were taking me to a big camp called Friendly Town but
title: The Fresh Air Fund;A City Girl Who Saw the Stars Returns the Favor

body: Commencement ceremonies for the City University of New York's Graduate School and University Center got off to a traffic-stopping start yesterday as participants walked from their building on 43d Street down the block to Town Hall. Counterparts at another CUNY school, John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan, found their way to Madison
title: COMMENCEMENTS;For CUNY Graduates, Long Trek to a Diploma

body: What is Olympics music? Is it a soundtrack for struggle, victory or peace? Is it a brassy fanfare, thunderous group drumming or streamlined pop? Is it Greek, American, African or global? For the last year, these questions have been confronting some of the country's top music producers and performers, from pop stars like Gloria Estefan and Billy Ray
title: THE POP LIFE;Meeting An Olympic Challenge

body: Trains may be slower and graffiti more prevalent, but by one measure, New York City's subway service keeps improving: the cars run longer and longer without breaking down. Drive an automobile hard every day and you don't expect it to be more reliable four years after you bought it. But that is exactly what has happened to New York City's fleet of
title: Subway Cars Perform Better Even as They Age

body: Alice Margaret Rubin, a daughter of Margaret and Harry Rubin of York, Pa., was married yesterday to Mark Edward Schone, a son of Harlan Schone of Williamsburg, Va., and the late Marilyn Schone. Judge Janice C. Volkman, an administrative law judge in Philadelphia for the Social Security Administration, officiated at Bargemusic in Brooklyn. Ms.
title: WEDDINGS;Alice M. Rubin, Mark E. Schone

body: When I come here," Kim Faiella says, looking out across the Red Hook harbor, "I feel like I'm in Edward Hopper-land." Ms. Faiella, a painter, is talking about the light -- broad and even, bouncing off the waves and across the low-lying buildings of Red Hook, creating a mood reminiscent of the landscapes of Hopper, the American realist painter.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK;On the Waterfront, a Snug Harbor for Artists (For Now)

body: Members of a Hasidic patrol group who fought with a black man in Crown Heights on Thursday night violated police rules intended to prevent vigilantism when they chased down a crime suspect instead of simply calling the police, police officials said yesterday. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said the group's leaders would be called in by the Police
title: Hasidic Patrol Group Faces Questions After a Crown Heights Clash

body: A police unit equipped with a battering ram and a sledgehammer and carrying a search warrant burst into the Jameel Grocery, a bodega under the rusting tracks of the Z train in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and arrested three clerks one day last week on charges that they sold marijuana to an undercover officer. As they handcuffed the clerks, one, Eric
title: Brooklyn Drug Sweeps Begin to Make Inroads

body: A young man looked up from his newspaper Friday morning, briefly noted the cityscape trundling by outside the F train, and returned to his paper. He looked up again a couple of minutes later, wrinkled his brow, sighed, and said, to no one in particular, "We're still not at Church Avenue? I hate this train." Those words from Danny Slotkin, a
title: Passengers Are Frustrated by Slower Commutes on Subways

body: TRAVELING along an elevated line with a birds-eye view of the industrial and inner-city streetscapes, housetops and church spires of North Brooklyn, the J train passes over Williamsburg and Bushwick before arriving at once-rural Cypress Hills on its way to Jamaica Center. Much of the housing stock in the multi-ethnic, multiracial community was
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Cypress Hills;An Evolving Northeast Brooklyn Enclave

body: Few legends haunt the imagination of New Yorkers of a certain intellectual or literary bent more than tales of the circles, salons and other highbrow hobnobbings that were once a feature of city life. It has become de rigueur in some quarters to dismiss the possibility that anything these days could measure up, to opine wearily that such circles
title: 90's Revival: Positive Power of Thinking

body: IN the last decade, the lust for better beers has given rise to hundreds of small breweries throughout the country. Many of them took root on the West Coast. But New York is catching up with a vengeance and becoming as serious as Seattle is about beer. This year as many as eight brewery-restaurants are expected to open in Manhattan. Two breweries
title: Finally, New York Takes to Brew Pubs

body: New York City's effort to shore up the crumbling Manhattan Bridge will take about 10 years longer and almost $300 million more than officials had predicted when the repairs began in 1982. The repairs, which have cut two subway connections between Manhattan and Brooklyn for periods of more than 10 years each and have clogged roads and highways in
title: Neglect of Manhattan Bridge Takes Toll in Time and Money

body: A 42-year-old postal worker has confessed to killing five prostitutes, dismembering their bodies and disposing of them in garbage bins on Long Island and in Yonkers over the last five years, the police said today. The suspect, Robert Shulman of Hicksville, hung his head and trembled as he was led from the police station this morning for arraignment
title: Man Arrested In L.I. Killings Of 5 Prostitutes

body: It is people like the man in the black beret who make Marisol Colon get off the street by dusk. With a nervous stride and darting eyes, he paces the corner of Glenmore and Chestnut. A young woman with French braids tells him that she wants to talk, but not with strangers standing close by. They move to a doorway where he quickly places something in
title: Hopeful East New Yorkers Await Police Drug Sweep

body: Defying the conventional wisdom that drug dealing is an ineradicable plague, the New York City Police Department next week will put up to 3,000 officers and weapons ranging from new computer software to hydraulic battering rams into its biggest assault ever on neighborhood pushers. While skeptical criminologists cite a history of failed antidrug
title: Police to Start Big Offensive Against Drugs

body: I never thought for a second that Lucy would jump." Sarah Jessica Parker is speaking of her character in "If Lucy Fell," the new movie comedy in which two roommates (Parker and Eric Schaeffer) make a pact to leap off the Brooklyn Bridge if they haven't found true love by the time they turn 30. "Perhaps," the actress adds, noting the film's
title: Sunday March 24, 1996: FALLING FOR LUCY;Look Before You Leap

body: Transit Authority managers know so little about how subways are actually operated that they have not come up with a way to prevent train operators from driving through stop signals, top Federal safety investigators said today. Running signals is so common and so dangerous that it has been the cause of seven accidents injuring 115 people since July
title: U.S. Faults Transit Agency Over Running of Signals

body: They could be brothers, almost. Both are powerful Orthodox Jewish politicians from the same part of Brooklyn. Both won their first elections in 1982, both have ambitions far beyond Borough Park and Flatbush, and both have been subjected to questions about their finances. One even played the saxophone at the other's wedding. But this is politics,
title: The Gladiators of Borough Park;Rivals Compete for Power in an Orthodox Arena

body: SHORTLY after midnight at a recent party in a midtown Manhattan loft, Howard Goldkrand sat slumped on a couch. Below his seat was a speaker, which rumbled and reverberated through the sofa cushions as a disk jockey known as Spooky mixed records full of swooshing electronics and heavy, heavy bass. "You know what this is?" Mr. Goldkrand asked,
title: At the Clubs, Murmurs and Ambient Music

body: Three men were being questioned by the police in Queens last night in connection with a carjacking on Tuesday in which a 17-year-old Brooklyn girl was critically injured. No charges were immediately filed against the men, who were being held at the 115th Precinct in Jackson Heights, officials said. It was not immediately clear what led to the
title: 3 Questioned in Carjacking That Hurt Girl

body: Two men taking a truck for a test drive yesterday with a salesman in Queens threw the salesman out and, chased by the police, sped into Brooklyn, where they struck and critically injured a 17-year-old girl. The victim, Rachel Teitelbaum, was walking on a sidewalk with three other girls after classes at a Talmudic seminary when the truck, a shiny
title: Carjackers Fleeing Police Strike Pedestrian

body: In the summer of 1992, when a city contractor began sandblasting on the Williamsburg Bridge, Susan Pellegrino watched in horror as dust with dangerous levels of lead doused her neighborhood. After she and her neighbors complained, the state ordered the work suspended. Now, sandblasting on the bridge towers is about to resume in Ms. Pellegrino's
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WILLIAMSBURG;Sandblasting Safety Tent Draws Critics

body: Cigar smoke billowing behind him, James Grotto strode grandly across the room as he summoned his troops to storm a heavily fortified Confederate ridge in the Battle of Gettysburg. "We don't see ourselves as murderers," he growled. "We just like to end wars real quick." Mr. Grotto moved on to sample a smorgasbord of equally hostile, ongoing
title: Scourge of Armies For A Few Hours;Saxons and Scots Confront Rat Race in Brooklyn

body: Opening a restaurant is always risky, simply because restaurants are a difficult business. Opening too far from a large enough corps of restaurantgoers worsens the odds, no matter how good the restaurant. Such was the unhappy experience of Stacy Pearl, whose beautifully renovated diner called Stacy's in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, served stylishly
title: 25 and Under

body: NEW YORK CITY More Power to Prosecutors? Seeking a far-reaching change in New York State's criminal justice system, Governor Pataki announced that he would propose legislation that would allow prosecutors to appeal sentences and bail amounts after judges set them. Under current state law, only defendants can appeal their sentences or bail amounts.
title: Metro Digest

body: The City Council yesterday overwhelmingly approved a new solid-waste management plan that will speed up the city's timetable for recycling "mixed paper" and will require residents in all five boroughs to recycle items like cereal boxes, milk cartons and junk mail by the middle of next year. Mixed-paper recycling is now required only on Staten
title: Solid-Waste Management Plan Wins Council Approval

body: A combination of basic detective work by a Hasidic volunteer patrol and the chance presence of a police car outside a Lower East Side bagel shop led to the capture yesterday of a Hasidic man whose estranged wife was found beaten unconscious on Saturday in her Monsey, N.Y., home. While groups like the Shomrim Volunteer Patrol have sometimes been
title: Hasidic Volunteers Help Find Suspect in Beating

body: From the barrios of Los Angeles to the cobblestone streets of Beacon Hill in Boston, officers in most large American police forces routinely patrol urban neighborhoods in one-officer cars. But not in New York. The city's first experiment with solo patrols ended in bloodshed in 1980, when an unaccompanied officer was slain during a test program. The
title: Issue of Lone-Officer Patrols Reignites a New York Debate

body: Brian Weil, a photographer who devoted much of his career to documenting life on society's margins and who helped found New York City's first needle exchange program, died over the weekend at his home in Manhattan. He was 41. His body was found late Monday evening, said Bruce Stepherson, a friend and colleague. Mr. Stepherson said an autopsy would
title: Brian Weil, 41, Photographer Who Founded Needle Exchange

body: For years, Pnina and Shmuel Klaver tried to abide by the Torah commandment to "be fruitful and multiply," but they had difficulty conceiving after their first two sons. On Monday, however, their prayers were answered fivefold. Mrs. Klaver gave birth to three girls and two boys by Caesarean section, each about one minute apart, starting at 11:48
title: It's a Boy, and a Girl, a Girl, a Girl and a Boy

body: Simon Breuer always warned the children he drove to school that it was safest to cross the street behind the school bus. It wasn't until Mirel Friedman, a 6-year-old handicapped girl in his charge, slipped on ice and fell under the rear wheels of his bus that he learned how wrong his warnings had been. Mr. Breuer, 23, a volunteer driver for a
title: Child's Death Raises Doubt Over Private-School Drivers' Training

body: While libraries in the rest of the city are connecting patrons to the information superhighway, Brooklyn's are limping along on the information dirt road. Only the Central Library at Grand Army Plaza and the Business Library in Brooklyn Heights have computers with Internet access, but they are only for librarians. In contrast, every public library
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN ON LINE;Libraries Lag on Surfing the Net

body: John Paul Valentine, 9 years old, has been living for most of his life in an Upper West Side foster home, where he was shielded from the drug dealing and crime of his family's neighborhood in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. But as he walked to school yesterday with his 20-year-old stepbrother, the city's lingering problem of drug-related street violence
title: Boy Shot as He Walked To School in Manhattan

body: In a move that officials say should lower garbage removal costs for businesses in New York City, one of the nation's biggest waste hauling companies said yesterday that it would enter the city's market by taking over a carting company that is under indictment as part of a Mafia-run cartel. USA Waste Services Inc., the nation's third largest
title: Texas Company Agrees to Buy Mafia-Linked Waste Hauler

body: Her mother died of AIDS, and so did her father, but it was not clear that Kai Evans was infected with the virus until she was 7 and caught chicken pox. Although Kai had a mild case of chicken pox, her recovery seemed to be taking too long. So her great-aunt and guardian, Sylvia Copes, took her to the hospital, where blood tests confirmed that she
title: A Young Victim of AIDS Gets a Proper Goodbye

body: The Brooklyn Navy Yard has long dominated life in Northern Brooklyn, from the days when thousands built warships to the recent battles over a city plan to build a huge incinerator there. The Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation recently received $739,000 from the Mayor's Office to assess the state of the 260-acre plot and figure out how to
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DEVELOPMENT;Community Consensus for the Navy Yard: Yes on Housing, No on Trash

body: For more than a decade, community groups have fought to get a nursing home built for Greenpoint's growing elderly population. But their efforts to build the home on the site of the old Greenpoint Hospital campus have competed with the city's need to house the homeless, 450 of whom now occupy a shelter on the site. Community residents have marched
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NORTHERN BROOKLYN;Push for Nursing Home Clears Big Hurdle

body: AT 87 years of age, Max Mandell is convinced that standing outside his Upper West Side town house in the cold, rain or snow is good for his health. Nearly every day since 1941, he just about bounds outside to greet the morning and the children who attend the Mandell School, making him the Cal Ripken Jr. of nursery school directors. He once went so
title: About New York;Preschoolers, His Fountain Of Youth at 87

body: Not even a blizzard could keep the vandals of Kiryas Joel from their appointed rounds. While the snow quieted New York City, this Satmar Hasidic village 50 miles away tallied another in a long line of violent episodes. Early Monday morning, the storm in full force, vandals broke a window in Joseph Waldman's Ford station wagon, threw in a flammable
title: OUR TOWNS;A Village Faces Another Kind Of Storm

body: Literally and figuratively, movies strut their stuff this week in a lineup that boasts brass bands and golden Oscars in numbers almost sufficient for a baseball team. To rouse the spirit, try STARS AND STRIPES FOREVER -- Wednesday at 8:30 P.M. on American Movie Classics. Henry Koster's affectionate 1952 tribute to John Philip Sousa stars Clifton
title: MOVIES THIS WEEK

body: The declaration was of triumph, if not total independence: Sanitation Department officials, conceding that the gargantuan amounts of snow in the city still posed enduring problems, said nonetheless that every street in the city had been plowed by yesterday -- except for the several dozen streets blocked by abandoned cars. title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: PLOWING;Snowbanks Aside, the Sanitation Department Declares a Victory

body: An already tough winter became harsher still last night, as temperatures in New York City dropped to their coldest of the season and the entire region headed into a weekend deep-freeze. By 11 P.M., the temperature in Central Park was 10 degrees, the lowest of the winter. As the wind came up, last night's cold made pedestrians pick up their pace and
title: Arctic Air Mass Stays Put For Deep-Freeze Weekend

body: WHIMSY seems to be the new directive for lighting fixtures. Tom Johnson, an artist in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, concocts original shades for friends in the restaurant business, then sells copies to the public. The series he designed for Food Bar in Chelsea is called "Skyline Cruise," because each shade is in the shape of a New York skyscraper (the
title: Currents;With Tongue In Cheek
